keyTakeAways: Enshittification is a concept coined by Cory Doctorow describing the degradation of internet platforms over time, where companies prioritize profit over user and business value.
The process occurs in three stages: Stage 1 (growth and user acquisition), Stage 2 (favoring business customers at user expense), and Stage 3 (profit maximization at user and business detriment).
Doctorow claims Facebook and Amazon have engaged in predatory pricing, data exploitation, algorithmic manipulation, and charging junk fees that erode margins for businesses and consumers.

Amazon is accused of cloning products and gaming search algorithms, with Doctorow citing studies showing the first search result on Amazon is 29% more expensive than the best match, and the best match is located 17 places down.
Doctorow attributes the degradation to a lack of competition and weak consumer protection regulations, particularly the consumer welfare standard in antitrust law.
He proposes solutions including stronger antitrust enforcement, the 'right-to-exit' policy (e.g., allowing users to take e-books with them), and increased interoperability between platforms.
Amazon and Facebook have responded by dismissing Doctorow's claims, asserting their platforms have improved and that fees are optional or reasonable.
The article highlights a growing anti-tech monopoly movement, especially overseas, and suggests policy solutions that are gaining traction across political spectra.

namedEntities.name: Enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the degradation of internet platforms into inferior experiences for users and businesses
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central concept of the article, explaining how platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber degrade over time due to profit-driven behavior.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Social media platform that Doctorow criticizes for data exploitation and algorithmic manipulation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a primary example of enshittification, with Doctorow alleging Facebook altered user feeds, forced publishers to publish more content, and charged publishers to boost posts.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: E-commerce platform accused of cloning products, charging junk fees, and gaming search algorithms
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Central to Doctorow’s critique; Amazon is cited for charging merchants 45–51 cents per dollar earned, manipulating search results, and reducing seller margins.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Ride-sharing platform included in Doctorow’s analysis of enshittification
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Represented as part of the broader pattern of internet platforms evolving from user-friendly to profit-optimized services, showing the phenomenon across industries.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Search engine and tech giant cited for its role in platform evolution
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included in Doctorow’s list of platforms undergoing enshittification, though not the central focus, illustrating the widespread nature of the phenomenon.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dictionarization body that added 'enshittification' to its dictionary

namedEntities.name: Planet Money
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NPR podcast and newsletter that published this article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides a platform for public discussion of internet platform ethics and economic models, amplifying the issue beyond academic or activist circles.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Nonprofit research and advocacy group cited by Doctorow for supporting claims about Amazon's fees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Adds credibility to Doctorow’s claims by referencing independent research on Amazon's seller margins and pricing practices.

namedEntities.name: Consumer Welfare Standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal doctrine in antitrust law that evaluates monopolistic behavior based on consumer harm and price increases
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Central to Doctorow’s critique of regulatory failure, as it allows companies to dominate markets without being challenged for anti-competitive behavior.

namedEntities.name: Network Effects
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Economic concept where a platform becomes more valuable as more users join
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Explains how platforms lock in users and grow, forming a foundation for enshittification by creating high switching costs and user dependence.

namedEntities.name: Switching Costs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Barriers to users leaving a platform, such as data lock-in or social connections
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key mechanism enabling enshittification, as users are discouraged from leaving due to difficulty and cost of migration.

namedEntities.name: Interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Technical concept allowing products or services to work together across platforms
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Proposed as a solution to platform monopolies, with Doctorow arguing that lack of interoperability enables companies to create artificial market control.

namedEntities.name: Right-to-Exit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Proposed policy allowing users to take data or content with them when leaving a platform
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key policy recommendation to counter enshittification by reducing user lock-in and incentivizing better platform behavior.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cory Doctorow introduces and expands on the concept of 'enshittification' — the degradation of internet platforms into inferior, profit-driven services — arguing that platforms like Facebook, Amazon, and Uber evolve from user-friendly startups into exploitative systems through three stages: user acquisition, business favoritism, and profit maximization. Doctorow claims Facebook manipulates user feeds with targeted ads and forces publishers to publish more content, while Amazon clones products, charges sellers junk fees (up to 51 cents per dollar), and distorts search results, leading to higher prices and lower quality for consumers. He attributes this decline to a lack of competition and weak antitrust enforcement, particularly the consumer welfare standard. He proposes solutions including stronger antitrust laws, interoperability, and a 'right-to-exit' policy to allow users to take their data with them. Amazon and Facebook have disputed the claims, asserting their platforms have improved and fees are optional or reasonable. The article highlights a growing global anti-monopoly movement and suggests policy changes that could reverse platform degradation.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
